understanding.p: A topic set is a collection of related topics that follow the same schema. Multiple topic sets can use the same schema. A topic set appears in the table of contents of a documentation set. By default, individual topics in the topic set are presented in alphabetical order under the topic set.
A document must have at least one topic set. Typically, a topic set belongs to a document set.

planning-question.planning-question-title: Do I neeed to create a new topic set?

planning-question-body.p: You could have a single topic set that contains all the topics; however, you typically want to use a topic set to group topics with related content and present the topic sets in a specific order in the table of contents. You may also want topics to follow different schemas. Grouping topics into different topic sets enables you to reuse topics in different topic sets and you can reuse topic sets in different documentation sets.

how-to-answer-body.p: If you want to do any of the following, you need a new topic set:

li.p: Create a new documentation set—every documentation set needs at least one topic set
Introduce a new schema—the topics in a topic set follow a single schema
Add new entry to the table of contents—there is one entry for each topic set in the table of contents
Change the order of topic sets in the table of contents—the topic set indicates its type which determines the order of the topic sets in the table of contents

doing.p: To add a topic set to the build system:

li.p: Create a topic set configuration file
Add a new /spfe/doc-set/topic-sets/topic-set to the SPFE configuration file

doing.p: You need to include the following elements in the topic set configuration file:

li.p: spfe: The root element that specifies the schema of the configuration file. SPFE provides the spfe-config schema, or you can define your own. Each build configuration file in the document must follow the same schema.

Define a unique TOPIC_SET_ID and a topic-set-id element. The TOPIC_SET_ID is used in file naming and must resolve to a valid file name. If you define a topic-set-id, the output for the topic set is stored in a subdirectory with the same name under the build-directory.
To define a title for your topic set, use the strings element.

/spfe/topic-set-type: It determines where your topic set appears in the table of contents and it must match one of the entries in the topic-set-type-order element in the SPFE configuration file. The elements are related; they must both be defined or omitted from the configuration file.

/spfe/sources: The list of directories that contain the contents of the topics. Contents include text, graphics, and information from outside sources that make up the topic content. You must specify each sub-element of /spfe/sources. While this element is optional, without it, the topic set has no content.
output-format: The document formats that you want the build system to create
/spfe/build/build-rules: The name of the ANT build rules file
/spfe/build/build-directory: Directory location used to store temporary files and the output generated during the build process
/spfe/deployment/output-path: The path to the folder that contains the document output. The value of this element is appended to /spfe/build/output-directory.
/spfe/scripts: The list of scripts to process the topic set; if you use an existing schema, you can reuse the existing scripts.

doing.p: If you want content at the top level folder, you need an index topic.
string - name that appears in the TOC
When you build your document, if your topic set appears in the table of contents in the order you specified, you have successfully added your topic set to the document.
